Graphical abstract Two charge transfer pathways of interface coupling and shallow traps. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting via semiconductors is an effective and feasible method for synthesizing renewable hydrogen (H2) fuels. In this study, β-In2S3 nanosheets were first grown on conductive glass. Then, we prepared P-doped β-In2S3 nanosheets with an amorphous InPOx overlayer via the incomplete phosphorization of pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets. When we used this material as photoanode in a PEC cell for water splitting, the photocurrent density drastically increased to 2.2 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V versus a reversible hydrogen electrode (vs. RHE). It enhanced 15 times as the pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets, which was only 0.15 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE (solar standard spectrum, 100 mW cm−2). The photoelectric conversion efficiency as high as 0.65% at a low potential of 0.81 V vs. RHE was achieved for the phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets. A series of experiments proved that the P-doping accelerated semiconductor charge-transport and the InPOx overlayer played cocatalyst role. We penetratingly investigated the pathway of charge transfer via femtosecond transient absorption. The results showed one pathway of charge transfer in pristine β-In2S3 photoanode. However, there were two pathways (core/shell coupling and shallow trap states) for charge transfer in the phosphorized β-In2S3 photoanode, which improved the performance of its PEC water oxidation. Keywords Photoelectrochemical In2S3 Nanosheet Water splitting Phosphorization 1 Introduction Hydrogen (H2) fuel is considered one of the most attractive sources of renewable and clean energy. Therefore, a multitude of investigations have focused on how to efficiently produce H2. Since the pioneering work on the photoelectrochemical (PEC) splitting of water by Honda and Fujishima, various semiconductor photoelectrode materials have been pursued intensely to enhance the efficiency of H2 generation and meet the demands for inexpensive hydrogen fuel [1,2]. In the PEC water splitting system for H2 generation, O2 evolution at the photoanode is generally regarded as the bottleneck process due to the four-electron transfer required to produce one O2 molecule in the half-reaction: 4OH− − 4e → O2 + 2H2O [3]. To address these issues in PEC water splitting, many physical and chemical strategies to engineer the photoanode semiconductors have been attempted [4–8], such as constructing nanostructure strategy [9–11], heterostructures [12,13], ion doping [14], defect engineering [15,16], co-catalysis [17,18], etc. Phosphorization treatment is also regarded as an effective method to improve the catalytic performance of the electrode materials in water splitting, including photoelectrocatalysis and electrocatalysis [19–24]. In the phosphating process, elemental phosphorus is introduced to the catalysts to induce P-doping or form metal phosphides, which facilitate charge mobility and promote charge transportation. However, the surfaces of the phosphorized samples are easily oxidized to their corresponding metallic oxides or phosphates, especially in aqueous or strongly oxidative environments [25]. Until now, although great advancements in PEC have been achieved with these studies of phosphorization-treated photoelectrodes, their pathway of charge transfer and recombination during PEC water splitting processes have rarely been researched. Indium sulfide (β-In2S3) is an n-type III-VI semiconductor that has been studied as a buffer layer in photovoltaic solar cells, which is currently considered as a promising candidate for photoanodes towards O2 evolution in the PEC water splitting [26–29]. Its band gap of (2.0–2.2 eV) allows for the harvesting and use of broadband visible light of the solar light spectrum [30,31]. So far, many efforts have been devoted to the nanoscale construction of β-In2S3 to improve PEC water oxidation. Considerable photocurrents and photooxidation have been achieved in the presence of sacrificial agents (such as Na2SO3 and Na2S) when the prepared β-In2S3 was used as the photoanode [32–34]. However, as far as we know, only a very low PEC O2 evolution efficiency was achieved in the absence of sacrificial agents. Recently, Hou and coworkers synthesized In2S3 atomic sheets decorated with In2O3 as a photoanode and reported a high photocurrent density of 1.28 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V versus a reversible hydrogen electrode (vs. RHE) in NaOH (1 M) [35]. Li and coworkers reported a higher photocurrent density of 1.64 mA cm−2 at 1.23 vs. RHE for the ZnO-modified In2S3 nanosheets [36]. Further improvements in the water oxidation efficiency of In2S3-based semiconductors still remains a challenge. In this work, we prepared pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets supported on fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glass substrate by a liquid-phase method. Then, the pristine In2S3 nanosheets were treated with a one-step phosphorization at 400 °C, inducing an amorphous InPOx layer on the nanosheet surface and P-doping in the In2S3 lattice (as shown in Scheme 1 ). The phosphorization-produced photoanode exhibited dramatically enhanced PEC activity for O2 evolution in water splitting. The photocurrent density reached 2.2 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE (solar standard spectrum, 100 mW cm−2), which is approximately 15 times as that of the pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets. The mechanism investigation shows that more fast charge-transfer are responsible for the improved PEC activity simultaneously along two pathways, that is core/shell coupling and shallow trap states, in the phosphorized β-In2S3 photoanodes. In contrast, only one pathway of charge transfer via shallow trap existed in pristine β-In2S3 photoanode. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemical agents Indium nitrate tetrahydrate (In(NO3)3·4H2O, AR) and thioacetamide (AR) were provided by J&K Ltd. Citric acid (Tianjin Fuchen chemical reagents) and ethanol (Beijing chemical works) were of analytical grade. Sodium hypophosphite (AR, 99.0%) was purchased from Aladdin. All chemicals were used as received with no further purification. 2.2 Material preparation Devices were fabricated on commercial fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) coated soda-lime glass substrates (dimensions: 45 × 10 × 1.1 mm, FTO thickness resistance 15 Ohm sq−1). These substrates were cleaned by subsequent ultrasonic-baths for 15 min (ultrapure water, ethanol, acetone, and ultrapure water). After that, the substrates were dried in an oven at 80 °C for 30 min. 2.3 Preparation of pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets supported on an FTO substrate In a vial of 20 mL, 120 mg indium nitrate tetrahydrate and 30 mg thioacetamide were dissolved in 12 mL ultrapure water. After stirring of 15 min, the pH value was adjusted into 2.7 by citric acid. A piece of the cleaned FTO substrate was placed into the above vial. Then the vial was covered and heated to 80 °C for 8 h. After that, the FTO substrate was taken out and cooled in the air. The conductive glass with orange products (In2S3) was repeatedly cleaned using by ethanol and ultrapure water, and was dried in a vacuum oven of 50 °C for 120 min. To compare with the phosphorized sample, the prepared β-In2S3 nanosheets supported on an FTO substrate were further annealed at 400 °C for 120 min under an N2 atmosphere for characterizations and PEC tests. 2.4 Phosphorization treatment of the β-In2S3 nanosheets The phosphorization treatment was performed in a tube furnace in high-purity N2 (99.999%). Typically, one piece of an FTO substrate supported with the prepared β-In2S3 nanosheets without annealing was placed on a porcelain boat. NaH2PO2 was loaded in another ceramic boat. The porcelain boat loaded with NaH2PO2 was placed in the top of the tube furnace. The two boats were separated by a distance of 1 cm in the tube furnace. The furnace was then heated to 400 °C in a flow of high-purity N2 at a heating rate of 3 °C per min, and maintained at this temperature for 120 min. Afterward, the tube furnace was naturally cooled to room temperature under N2 flow. After the tube was cooled to room temperature, the FTO with phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets was taken out and washed three times with deionized water, and then was dried in an oven at 50 °C. In addition, NaH2PO2 with a different amount (0.11, 0.33 and 0.55 mmol) was loaded in the ceramic boat to seek the optimum phosphorization conditions. 2.5 Preparation of phosphorized β-In2S3 on the TiO2 layer Both hydrochloric acid (6 mL) and deionized water (6 mL) were added to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and stirred vigorously for twenty minutes. Then, 200 μL of tetrabutyl titanate was added and stirred for one hour. After stirring, a clean FTO substrate was added into the mixed solution, and the conductive surface was faced down. After the autoclave was sealed and maintained at 170 °C for 5 h in a preheated oven, it was taken out and cooled at room temperature. After the FTO with titanium dioxide was taken out, it was washed for three times with deionized water. The titanium dioxide film deposited on the FTO was then used as a substrate to synthesize the phosphorized β-In2S3, and the synthetic method was the same as that described above. 2.6 Characterization The crystal structures of the samples were investigated on a Rigaku D/Max 2200 PC diffractometer (λ = 0.15418 nm). The XRD spectra were collected at a scanning speed of 4.0° per min over a 2θ range from 10 to 70°. Scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi S-4800) with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra were used to characterize the size, morphology, and elemental composition of the samples. High-resolution transition electron microscopy (HRTEM, GEOL-2010) was employed to observe the lattice fringes and crystalline structures. The components and surface of the β-In2S3 nanosheets were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses based on the C-C standard peak at 284.6 eV. The X-ray type is ESCALAB 250, and the light source was Monochromated Al Kα at 150 W. The XPS valence band edge (VBXPS) measurements were taken from −2 eV to 5 eV, where a narrow sweep is performed over this scan interval. The elemental compositions of the products were also analyzed via high-angle annular dark field-scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) imaging with EDX mapping. Visible absorption spectra were taken on a Shimadzu spectrometer (UV2550). FT-IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Frontier spectrometer on samples embedded in KBr pellets. 2.7 Femtosecond time-resolved absorption tests A Ti/sapphire femtosecond laser system provided the laser pulses for the femtosecond transient absorption measurements. A regenerative amplifier (Spectra Physics, Spitfire) seeded with a mode-locked Ti/sapphire laser (Spectra Physics, Tsunami) delivered the laser pulses at 800 nm (120 fs, 1 kHz), which were then divided into two components using a 9:1 beam splitter. The major component was sent to an optical parametric amplifier (Spectra Physics, OPA-800CF) to generate the pump pulses (400 nm, 130 fs, 1 kHz). The minor component was further attenuated and focused into a 3-mm sapphire plate to generate the probe pulses. A short-pass filter (SPF-750, CVI) was inserted into the probe beam to select the visible probe (420–750 nm). The time delay between the pump and probe beams was regulated through a computer-controlled motorized translation stage in the pump beam. The temporal resolution between the pump and probe pulses was determined to be ∼150 fs (FWHM). The transmitted light was detected by a CMOS linear image sensor (S8377-512Q, Hamamatsu). The excitation pulse energy was ∼100 nJ/pulse, as measured at the sample site. Analysis of the kinetic traces derived from the time-resolved spectra was performed using a nonlinear least-square fitting of a general sum-of-exponentials function after deconvolution of the instrument response function (IRF). All the spectroscopic measurements were carried out at room temperature. 2.8 Photoelectrochemical water splitting test PEC characterization was performed using a three-electrode system on an electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments 660D). A 350 W xenon lamp provided the illumination for the simulated solar light with a power density of 100 mW cm−2 (AM 1.5G). The working electrode had exposed β-In2S3 nanosheets with an area of 1.0 cm2. A saturated mercury (HgO) electrode was used as a reference, Pt mesh (1 cm2 surface area) was used as the cathode electrode, and 1 M NaOH was used as the electrolyte solution (pH = 14). The characteristic linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of the electrode were performed on an electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments 660D) at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1, where the start and stop potentials were 0.11 and 1.4 V (vs. RHE), respectively. Additionally, we evaluated the photoelectronic conversion efficiency using the equation: (1) η % = J m A · c m - 2 1.23 - V app P light × 100 % where η is the efficiency of photoelectronic conversion, Vapp is the applied bias (vs. RHE), J is the photocurrent density at the applied bias, and Plight is the incident light intensity at 100 mW cm−2 (AM 1.5G illumination). The measured potential with respect to the HgO reference electrodes (same as LSV) was converted to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) potential following the equation: (2) E RHE = E HgO + E θ HgO + 0.059 pH where EHgO is the applied potential against the HgO reference electrode, Eθ HgO = 0.098 V at 25 °C, and ERHE is the converted potential vs. RHE. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) Nyquist plots were measured under simulated sunlight using a three-electrode system in which the test conditions were measured at a voltage of 1.23 V vs. RHE and a frequency of 106 to 1 Hz, where the electrolyte solution is a 1 M NaOH solution (pH = 14). Mott-Schottky values were measured in an aqueous solution of 1.0 M NaOH at a frequency of 103 Hz at a scanning rate of 20 mV s−1, where the range of potential was −0.4–0.4 V (vs. RHE). The incident photon-to-electron conversion efficiency (IPCE) measurements of the pristine β-In2S3 and phosphorized β-In2S3 were tested at wavelengths from 300 to 680 nm at a potential of 1.23 V (vs. RHE) (7IMS1021, Saifan, Beijing instrument Co. Ltd). 3 Results and discussion The synthesis of phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheet arrays on FTO glass is illustrated in Scheme 1. First, pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets were grown on the FTO substrate by a simple solution-phase method. Then, phosphorization of the pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets was performed in a tube furnace with NaH2PO2 to form the phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets, in which the nanosheets were internally doped with phosphorous and externally coated with an amorphous InPOx overlayer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was employed to characterize the crystal structures and compositions of the samples. In Fig. 1 a, the XRD pattern of pristine β-In2S3 with no phosphorization (red curve) indicates two sets of diffraction peaks: one set belongs to the FTO substrate, and the other set could be indexed well to the standard diffraction data for cubic β-In2S3 phase (a = b = c = 10.73 Å, JCPDS No. 84-1385). After the phosphorization process at 400 °C, the XRD pattern of the product (black curve) shows nearly the same diffraction peaks as those of the pristine β-In2S3 sample. However, as shown in Fig. 1b and c, the magnifications of the (4 4 0) and (4 0 0) peaks show a shift towards the left compared to the pristine β-In2S3. This result suggests that the β-In2S3 nanosheets were successfully doped with P because the partial substitution of P element distorted the lattice. No clear diffraction of InPOx composition can be detected in the XRD pattern because of the amorphous nature. In addition, the two samples show similarly high crystallinity degrees of 93.4% (pristine) and 95.6% (phosphorized) for the In2S3 peaks, as calculated by the JADE program. The products supported on FTO substrates were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis. As shown in Fig. 1d, the FTO substrate is uniformly covered by β-In2S3 nanosheets that are standing vertically. The thickness of the pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets is approximately 12 nm (Fig. S1a, see SI), and the lateral diameter is approximately 200–400 nm. In contrast, Fig. 1e shows that the phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets maintained their two-dimensional structure, but their thickness increased to approximately 21 nm (Fig. S1b, see SI), increasing approximately 9 nm compared with the pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets. This was likely caused by phosphorization treatment. To further study the structure of the sample after phosphorization, we performed high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) on it, as shown in Fig. 2 a. It illustrates a set of lattices at the inner of crystals with spacings of 0.268 and 0.322 nm, which are consistent with the (4 0 0) and (3 1 1) planes of the P-doped β-In2S3, respectively. In addition, Fig. 2a shows an amorphous overlayer of 4–5 nm coating on the β-In2S3 nanosheets surface. In contrast, no amorphous layer was detected in the pristine β-In2S3 (in Fig. S4). The InPOx shell should be formed by surface phosphorization and following oxidation in air. To analyze the chemical composition of the amorphous InPOx layer, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was carried on it. Fig. 2c–f shows the elemental distribution of the nanosheets corresponding to the selected area of Fig. 2b. The images (Fig. 2c, e, and f) indicates the presence of In, O, and P throughout the nanosheets. However, Fig. 2d shows the S elemental mapping distribution is smaller than the In, O, and P, indicating the S only located at the inner of nanosheet. Therefore, the results indicate that the amorphous overlayer on the surface of the nanosheets should be indium phosphate (InPOx) [25]. To further confirm the surface state and composition of the phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets, the XPS technique was employed to investigate the sample. For comparison, the pristine β-In2S3 sample was also characterized simultaneously. Fig. 3 a shows the high-resolution XPS (HRXPS) pattern of In element in the two samples. For pristine β-In2S3 sample, two peaks at 444.7 and 452.2 eV are in good agreement with 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 orbits in In2S3 [37]. In contrast, the phosphorized β-In2S3 indicates two new peaks at 445.5 eV and 453.1 eV in the HRXPS pattern, which coincide with the reported In 3d5/2 and In 3d3/2 in the InPO4 [38]. This illustrates well that the formation of InPOx at the surface of the phosphorized β-In2S3 sample. Correspondingly, the phosphorized β-In2S3 sample shows the binding energy of P element at 133.4 eV and 134.4 eV (Fig. 3b), in good agreement with the characterized 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbits of P5+ in PO4 3− [39]. It indicates the phosphorized nanosheets surface were oxidized into InPOx. No obvious peaks of doped P in In2S3 were detected in Fig. 3b, which should be caused by their small amount and location at the inner of nanosheets. Fig. 3c displays the O 1s spectrum of the pristine β-In2S3 and phosphorized β-In2S3. The pristine β-In2S3 sample showed a weak binding energy peak of O element at 531.8 eV, corresponding to the –OH in the adsorbed water molecular [40]. In contrast, the phosphorized β-In2S3 shows three deconvoluted peaks. The peak at 532.4 eV corresponds to the P-O bonds [39]; the peak at 531.7 eV corresponds to the adsorbed –OH [40]. The peak at 530.9 eV corresponds to oxygen vacancies [41], which were induced by the incomplete surface oxidation of the β-In2S3 nanosheets. Moreover, its large peak area indicates a lot of oxygen vacancies existed in the phosphorized β-In2S3 (as Table S1). This well confirmed the amorphous layer is InPOx (x < 4) rather than InPO4. Fig. 3d shows the HRXPS patterns of S element in the two samples. The pristine β-In2S3 shows two obvious binding energies at 161.4 eV and 162.3, corresponding to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 orbits of S in In2S3 [37]. In contrast, the phosphorized β-In2S3 shows a relative weak band of S element, caused by the In2S3 locating under the InPOx shell. Furthermore, the peaks of S in the phosphorized β-In2S3 both shifted to higher binding energy. This shift illustrates the electron coupling between the InPOx shell and In2S3, inducing the electron cloud density decreased around S atoms. Additionally, the Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Fig. S8) spectrum of the phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets shows a characterized peak of P-O bond at1096 and 1048 cm−1, illustrating the existence of the group of -POx [42]. The light absorption capabilities of the semiconductor electrode are of crucial importance and can largely determine the ultimate energy conversion efficiency in the PEC process. In consideration of this, we characterized the UV–visible absorption spectra of pristine and phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the pristine β-In2S3 showed a clear absorption in the visible light range from ∼600 nm to 400 nm. In contrast, the phosphorized sample absorbed light between 400 and 600 nm with negligible intensity enhancement. By transforming the spectral deformation into (ahν)2 vs. photon energy (hν/eV) plotted at the onset region, the Eg values of the pristine β-In2S3 were estimated to be 2.1 eV, as shown in Fig. 4b, which is in good agreement with that of the reported n-type semiconductor, β-In2S3 (2.0–2.3 eV) [30]. However, the phosphorized β-In2S3 exhibited a smaller band gap of 1.9 eV, which would be favorable for absorbing visible light and producing more photogenerated carriers within a semiconductor. The prepared pristine β-In2S3 and phosphorized β-In2S3 on FTO were tested as photoanodes in water splitting in 1 M NaOH with the irradiation of Xe lamp (AM1.5G, 100 mW cm−2). As shown in Fig. 5 a, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) scans of the two samples exhibited almost negligible dark currents in the potential range of 0.1–1.4 V vs. RHE. Under irradiation, the effective photocurrent density of the pristine β-In2S3 reached 0.15 mA cm−2 at the normal potential of water oxidation (1.23 V vs. RHE). In contrast, the phosphorized β-In2S3 supported on FTO exhibited a highly increased current density when the bias was larger than 0.3 V vs. RHE. Then, it reached 2.2 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is approximately 15 times as that of the pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets. Notably, this high photocurrent density was obtained without any sacrificial agent in the electrolyte. Correspondingly, the photoelectric conversion efficiency of the phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets was much higher than that of the pristine β-In2S3 across the whole potential range tested, as shown in Fig. 5b. The highest efficiency achieved by 0.65% at 0.81 V vs. RHE for the phosphorized β-In2S3 photoanode. Nyquist plots of the β-In2S3 nanosheets were also studied through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at a bias of 1.23 V vs. RHE (Fig. 5c). Correspondingly, an equivalent circuit model for ESI was established and is shown in the inset of Fig. 5c, in which Rs represents all the resistors connected in series in the electrochemical battery, Rct stands for the internal impedance, Rtrap stands for the impedance of a carrier across the semiconductor/electrolyte interface, Cbulk represents the electric capacity in the depletion layer of the semiconductor, and Ctrap represents the electric capacity at the surface of the semiconductor photoanode [14,43]. The impedance values of the different parts of the pristine β-In2S3 and phosphorized β-In2S3 are listed in SI (Table S1, see ESI). Among them, Rtrap of the phosphorized β-In2S3 was noticeably reduced from 7472 Ω in the pristine sample to 3069 Ω, demonstrating favorable charge transfer at the interface of the semiconductor/electrolyte after the phosphorization process. Furthermore, the incident photon-to-electron conversion efficiency (IPCE) measurements were also obtained to assess the contribution of monochromatic light to the photocurrent density at a potential of 1.23 V (vs. RHE), and the results are presented in Fig. 5d. We compute the IPCE of pristine β-In2S3 and phosphorized β-In2S3 for water oxidation using Eq. (1) [44]: (3) IPCE ( 100 % ) = 1240 × I ( m A / c m 2 ) P light ( m W / c m 2 ) × λ ( n m ) × 100 % where I is the photocurrent density measured at a specific wavelength, Plight is the light power density measured at a dedicated wavelength and λ is the wavelength of incident light. The phosphorized β-In2S3 photoanode exhibited an effectively enhanced IPCE in comparison to the pristine β-In2S3 photoanode in the studied range (380–540 nm). The maximum IPCE value for the pristine β-In2S3 was 26.4% at 400 nm; in contrast, it produced a maximum IPCE value of 54.6% for phosphorized β-In2S3 at 400 nm. These results indicate that the absorbed photons of phosphorized β-In2S3 can be utilized more efficiently. In addition, it shows the use of visible light between 400 and 500 nm plays a dominant role in the photon-to-electron conversion rather than ultraviolet light. To investigate the effect of InPOx shell and P-doping on improving the PEC water oxidation, a series of experiments were performed by using the pristine and phosphorized β-In2S3 samples. We tested the LSV curves of the two samples for water oxidation in the dark. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the onset potential of the phosphorized β-In2S3 for water oxidation is 0.32 V vs. RHE, far negative than that of pristine β-In2S3 in the dark. This indicates clearly that InPOx shell acted as water oxidation cocatalysts to increase surface holes transfer into the electrolyte [42,45]. In PEC water splitting, cocatalysts (such as Co-Pi, FeOOH, and Ce-Pi) [17,42,46], are often used as to make for capturing the photogenerated holes and accelerating the charge separation in the semiconductor to arrive at the cocatalyst surface. Herein, it is the first time to discover that indium phosphate can also be developed as efficient cocatalysts. The carrier densities were investigated using by Mott-Schottky analysis (Fig. 6b). The carrier densities calculated from the slopes of the Mott-Schottky plots for pristine β-In2S3 and phosphorized β-In2S3 are 3.3 × 1019 cm−3 and 1.7 × 1021 cm−3, respectively [47]. The carrier density of the phosphorized β-In2S3 was enhanced by approximately 2 orders of magnitude compared with that of pristine β-In2S3. This should be related to the P-doping in the β-In2S3 nanosheets. To further prove the accelerated charge transport and transfer in the phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets, we conducted LSV tests in 1 M NaOH containing 0.5 M H2O2 as a hole scavenger (Fig. S12 See SI). For an n-type semiconductor photoanode, a fast hole capture agent, H2O2, in the electrolyte can quickly separate holes from the photoanode surface. Due to the rapid rate of holes transfer by the oxidation of H2O2 at photoanode/electrolyte interface, it can be assumed that the surface transfer rate is 100% (ηsurf (H2O2) ≈ 100%) [48–50]. We compute the separation efficiency at the electrode surface for water oxidation using the relation (4) η s u r f = J H 2 O / J H 2 O 2 Fig. 6c shows the surface transfer efficiencies of the pristine and phosphorized β-In2S3, which were 29% and 75% at 1.23 V vs. RHE, respectively. The surface charge transfer efficiency increased approximately 2.6 times after the β-In2S3 nanosheets underwent phosphorization treatment. This increasing verified the amorphous InPOx plays the cocatalysts role as analyzed above, making for the charge transfer between the InPOx shell and electrolyte. On the other hand, the carrier transport efficiency (ηtrans) ratio of the phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets was estimated to be approximately 4.8 times as that of pristine β-In2S3 (see SI), which confirmed the accelerated charge transport in the P-doped β-In2S3 nanosheets. To penetratingly explore the effect of phosphorization on the charge transfer behaviors for the enhanced PEC activity, femtosecond transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy was performed on the pristine and phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets. As shown in Fig. 7 a and b, the TA spectra showed different lifetime but identical spectral styles, including a negative band below 550 nm due to ground state bleaching (GSB) and a positive band over 550 nm due to polaron absorption. The identical spectral styles indicated that the absorption was attributed to the In2S3 or P-doped In2S3 semiconductor, and the presence of the outer InPOx layer barely affected light irradiation on the semiconductor nanosheets. However, they show different lifetime from Fig. 7a and b. Further, Fig. 7c shows the time-resolved absorption decay curves for the two tested samples, which were fitted by a tri-exponential exponential decay function. Table 1 shows that the polaron signal decays tri-exponentially with time constants of 1.7 ps, 26 ps and 1400 ps for the phosphorized β-In2S3 on FTO, and 4.0 ps, 80 ps and 2000 ps for pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets. All of the three lifetimes were reduced after phosphorization, and as a result, the average lifetime of the phosphorization-treated samples decreased to 230 ps, shorter than that of pristine β-In2S3 (498 ps). This reduces of lifetime indicates a more rapid charge transfer and a more efficient electron-hole separation between the core of P-doped β-In2S3 and the shell of amorphous InPOx, which is similar to those reported in Refs. [51,52]. (5) C i % = a i / ∑ i = 1 , 2 , 3 a i In addition, the charge transfer and recombination behaviors of the prepared P-doped β-In2S3 coupled with an InPOx layer were investigated in detail. The percent contribution of a lifetime component is directly related to the availability of a particular decay pathway [53]. The relative weight of the τi component (Ci%) was determined using Eq. (5) [54]. The ai is the amplitude (pre-exponential factor) of the individual components. The calculated Ci% values of the two samples are listed in Table 1. The τ1 lifetime is associated with defects or the surface states in the semiconductor. Its contribution increased from 42.1% to 50.9% after the β-In2S3 nanosheets were treated by phosphorization, which was likely induced by introduced defects during P-element doping. Furthermore, both relative weights of the τ1 component (42.1% and 50.9%) were dominant, indicating many defects in the 2D nanosheet surface. The τ2 composite is related to direct band edge decay in the semiconductor. This direct recombination also clearly became faster in the sample after phosphorization treatment due to charge transfer to the InPOx layer. At the same time, the percent contribution of τ2 decreased (38.0 vs. 32.8%) after phosphorization treatment, indicating the weakened pathway of band-to-band exciton recombination, which is beneficial for PEC applications. In Table 1, the relative weight (C3%) of τ3 is associated with the shallow trap states (i.e., trap states at or near the band edge) [53,55]. The long-lived photoinduced charge (on the order of nanoseconds) is stored in these shallow traps before final recombination. The long lifetime is therefore beneficial for the charge transfer of holes from the shallow traps to the surface for water oxidation under the PEC external potential. Table 1 shows that the τ3 lifetime became shorter after phosphorization due to the photoexcited charge transfer directly to the InPOx layer, as mentioned above. The relative weight changed slightly (19.9% vs. 16.3%), indicating a second pathway for charge transfer to the InPOx surface via the shallow traps. Considering the above femtosecond TA spectra studies as well as energy band structures of the two semiconductor photoanodes (see details in Fig. S13), the charge transfer mechanism for the pristine and phosphorized In2S3 nanosheets photoanodes were schemed in Fig. 8 . It shows the shallow traps are the main pathway for photoexcited charge transfer in pristine In2S3 nanosheets, which is shown as PW I in Fig. 8a. However, for the phosphorized In2S3, besides the pathway of shallow trap (shown as PW I in Fig. 8b), an additional charge-transfer pathway, via the coupling between the P-doped β-In2S3 and the InPOx shell (shown as PW II in Fig. 8b), can accelerate the charge transfer to arrive at the InPOx surface due to its cocatalysis role. 4 Conclusion In summary, a phosphosization treatment was applied to β-In2S3 nanoplates supported on an FTO substrate in order to P-dope the material and introduce an amorphous InPOx layer with ∼5 nm thickness. When used as a photoanode for water splitting, the phosphosization-treated β-In2S3 nanoplates showed extreme improvements in their activity compared to an untreated sample under the same conditions. Compared to that of pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets, the photocurrent density of the treated β-In2S3 photoanode highly increased to 2.2 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, and the photoelectric conversion efficiency reached 0.65% at 0.81 V vs. RHE. An in-depth study confirmed that the coupling between the InPOx layer and the P-doped the β-In2S3 semiconductor induced faster charge transfer between the core and shell components. The holes in shallow traps also moved towards the photoanode surface under the external electric field and promoted water oxidation. Our work provides a promising method and detailed charge transfer studies for engineering semiconductors via phosphorization to enhance their PEC activity in water splitting. coredata.dc:description: Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting via semiconductors is an effective and feasible method for synthesizing renewable hydrogen (H2) fuels. In this study, β-In2S3 nanosheets were first grown on conductive glass. Then, we prepared P-doped β-In2S3 nanosheets with an amorphous InPOx overlayer via the incomplete phosphorization of pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets. When we used this material as photoanode in a PEC cell for water splitting, the photocurrent density drastically increased to 2.2 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V versus a reversible hydrogen electrode (vs. RHE). It enhanced 15 times as the pristine β-In2S3 nanosheets, which was only 0.15 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE (solar standard spectrum, 100 mW cm−2). The photoelectric conversion efficiency as high as 0.65% at a low potential of 0.81 V vs. RHE was achieved for the phosphorized β-In2S3 nanosheets. A series of experiments proved that the P-doping accelerated semiconductor charge-transport and the InPOx overlayer played cocatalyst role. We penetratingly investigated the pathway of charge transfer via femtosecond transient absorption. The results showed one pathway of charge transfer in pristine β-In2S3 photoanode. However, there were two pathways (core/shell coupling and shallow trap states) for charge transfer in the phosphorized β-In2S3 photoanode, which improved the performance of its PEC water oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: P-doped In2S3 nanosheets coupled with InPOx overlayer: Charge-transfer pathways and highly enhanced photoelectrochemical water splitting
